general.headline: Doctor of Law - JD at Monash University
general.description:
Sione began working as a legal advisor for persons navigating the UNHCR RSD process in Malaysia at the beginning of 2017. Prior to this she completed research in the field of International Refugee Law, including the principle of non-refoulement, third-country deals, strategic litigation as well as the effect of trauma on credibility during RSD assessment. 

Sione is a recent graduate of the Bachelor of Arts (International Studies) (Honours) at RMIT University, having graduated with first-class honours and receiving the Outstanding Honours Thesis award for her research on Israel鈥檚 treatment of refugees. 

Sione has significant experience working with people seeking asylum, including both legal work (African Refugee Development Centre, Israel and Asylum Access, Malaysia) as well as casework experience (Asylum Seeker Resource Centre, Australia).

general.headline: Senior Partner, Arnold Bloch Leibler I National Chairman, AIJAC
general.description:
Mark Leibler AC is one of Australia's leading tax lawyers and corporate strategists. As senior partner of Arnold Bloch Leibler and head of its tax practice, he acts in the tax affairs of Australia's largest businesses and corporate leaders. Under Mark's leadership, the firm鈥檚 tax practice has achieved outstanding results in complex tax audits, corporate tax strategy, and tax, estate and trust planning.

Mark has a profound commitment to Indigenous rights and reconciliation. In December 2015, the Prime Minister of Australia and Leader of the Opposition announced Mark鈥檚 appointment as Co-Chair of the Referendum Council on Constitutional Recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples. The Council reported in June 2017. 

Mark is also deeply involved in Jewish affairs. In 2014 the Jerusalem Post named him one of the 50 most influential Jews in the world. He is National Chairman of the Australia/Israel & Jewish Affairs Council and a Governor of the Australia Israel Chamber of Commerce. 

In 2014 Mark was awarded The University of Melbourne鈥檚 highest honour, the degree of Doctor of Laws honoris causa. The university acknowledged Mark鈥檚 significant contribution, particularly in the areas of support for Indigenous rights, service to the Jewish community and excellence in law. Mark was also appointed as a member of the University of Melbourne Council, the governing body of the University, by the Victorian Government, effective 1 April 2017.

In 2005 Mark was appointed a Companion in the General Division of the Order of Australia in recognition of his service to business, to the law, particularly in the areas of taxation and commercial law, to the Jewish community internationally and in Australia, and to reconciliation and the promotion of understanding between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians.

general.headline: Solicitor; Sunshine Coast Law Association Committee Member; Volunteer Solicitor at Suncoast Community Legal Centre
general.description:
I have recently completed my Bachelor of Laws/Bachelor of Arts (Majoring in Justice and Minoring in Legal Studies) at the University of the Sunshine Coast (USC) and my Graduate Diploma of Legal Practice (GDLP) at the College of Law. I was admitted to the Supreme Court of Qld on 27 August 2018 and to the High Court of Australia on 11 September 2018.

In 2017, I was a finalist in the 2017 Lawyers Weekly Women in Law Awards in the Law Student of the Year Category

I was the 2015-2017 Vice-President of Events for the USC Law Students' Association (USC LSA). This role required me to prepare, facilitate and review all events run by the Association. The role of VP Events allowed me to be an influential figure within the USC student body. I worked closely with the rest of the executive in delivering educational, social, competitive and formal events to our members. 

I was the Student Representative for the Women's Law Association of Queensland (WLAQ) in 2017/18 .

In 2016, I was a member of the USC Student Representative Council as the Law School representative.

In 2017/18, I was the Vice-President (Administration) for the Australian Law Students' Association. This role allowed me to connect and work with Law Students from around Country and internationally. 

I was recently elected to the Sunshine Coast Law Association (SCLA) as a committee member. I have been looking forward to the opportunity to be a committee member of SCLA since graduating from USC earlier this year.

I have been volunteering at Suncoast Community Legal Service since early 2017 after completing a one-day a week placement there in 2016. I am excited to be able to volunteer there as a lawyer once I am admitted in August.

I have a keen interest in Criminal Law, Domestic Violence and Family Law and Wills and Estates. Alternatively, I hope to one day work in Sports Law, combining my passion for the law with my love of sport, particularly AFL, the Western Bulldogs, Cricket and Netball.

jobs.description:
180DC is a global, student-led consulting group that collaborates with not for profits in
      order to meet their organisational objectives and enhance their social impact.
      

    
      

    In 2018, I returned to 180DC as a team leader. I co-led a team of five consultants in
      order to develop a communications and fundraising plan for a newly formed
      community legal centre.  I have gained important insights into managing and
      
      motivating teams and closely collaborating with clients to achieve meaningful change.

I currently sit in the Applied Legal Technology team as a casual paralegal. I provide assistance to a range of practise groups, working predominantly with the Disputes and Investigations team. My core responsibilities include completing legal research on procedural and substantive questions and assisting in large-scale document management.

I currently work as a front-office receptionist for a high performing real estate agency in Kensington. I complete back end to ensure the smooth operation of the sales and property management teams. This involves liaising between agents and clients, responding to enquiries and troubleshooting problems, and a range of other administrative tasks.

As a research assistant to policy advisors at WLSV, I conducted research on a wide variety of legal matters. I analysed developments and proposals for reform within Australian family law, including child protection, family violence and property settlement proceedings. My research helped inform WLSV's strategic positioning as a leading stakeholder within women's legal rights and advocacy in Australia.

As a part of Melbourne Law School's Public Interest Law Initiative (PILI) program, I undertook a four week placement with FKCLC's Police Accountability Project.

My responsibilities included: 
- Taking instructions from solicitors and attending client meetings 
- Drafting letters of advice 
- Maintaining client files 
- Document management and document review 
- Legal research

As a part of the Aurora Project, I undertook a four week placement with the Northern Land Council (NLC). I assisted two busy legal teams with matters relating to Native Title and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 (Cth). 

My responsibilities included:
- Drafting and editing memorandums, lease agreements, letters and briefs to counsel 
- Preparing consultation materials for traditional owners 
- Taking detailed minutes of consultation meetings with traditional owners 
- Preparing case summaries and researching case law surrounding Native Title and Land Rights 
- Gained an awareness of the unique challenges of cross cultural communication

Project Respect assists women experiencing exploitation in the Victorian sex industry. I worked closely with other volunteers and social workers in order to prepare to the Commonwealth Inquiry on a Modern Day Slavery Act. During this time, I researched Australia's federal anti-trafficking legislation, and conducted a comparative analysis with UK's anti-trafficking regime. I also evaluated the proposals for reform in light of Australia's international human rights obligations.

Over the course of a semester, I worked in a team to assess the feasibility of creating a membership scheme for MWF, with the objective of deepening the festival's engagement with existing and prospective audience members. This was an excellent opportunity to build foundational skills in strategy consulting and gain exposure to working in team-centred environments.

Collective Shout is a not-for-profit organisation aiming to encourage positive representations of women in media and advertising. I was responsible for the supervision and management of volunteers and events in Victoria. I aimed to engage current and prospective volunteers in a way that met the organisation's evolving demands, whilst ensuring long term volunteer retention and satisfaction.

I assisted a sole practitioner with various administrative duties. 

My responsibilities included: 
- Editing and formatting documents 
- Developing a filing system for archives and precedents 
- Conducting property searches using InfoTrack.

general.headline: Professor of International Law | Director, Law Futures Centre at Griffith University
general.school: Saint Louis University School of Law
general.description:
Don Anton is a leading international lawyer. He is holds the inaugural Chair in International Law at Griffith University Law School. From 2000- 2015 he taught at the Australian National University as a Lecturer, Senior Lecturer, Associate Professor and Professor of Law. He has been a Visiting Professor at a number of law schools, including Michigan, Alabama, and, most recently, Yangon. He has also lectured in International Environmental Law and Trade and the Environment in the LL.M programs at the University of Sydney and the University of Adelaide, and has been a Course Instructor for the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP). 

Anton has an active international law practice. In 2017, he appeared as Counsel for the IUCN World Commission on Environmental Law, arguing in favor of extraterritorial application of human rights obligations breached by environmental harm, in advisory proceedings before the Inter-American Court of Human Rights. He has served as Counsel for the IUCN in advisory proceedings before the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea in the 2013 Request for an Advisory Opinion Submitted by the Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission (Case No. 21). In 2010 he also appeared as Counsel on behalf of the IUCN in the Seabed Disputes Chamber of the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea in Case No. 17, Responsibilities and Obligations of States Sponsoring Persons and Entitities with Respect to Activities in the Area. In 2011 and again in 2014, Anton served as Counsel and Attorney of Record for thrity eminent amici curiae international law professors on issues of public international law in Chevron v. Donziger -- an appeal in the U.S. involving a US$8.4 billion dollar judgment in Ecuador against Chevron. In 2012, Anton appeared as Counsel and amicus curiae on behalf of Australian international lawyers in the Supreme Court of the United States in Kiobel v. Royal Dutch Petroleum in support of human rights claims of the Ogoni people of Nigeria.

general.description:
www.audreybester.com

Audrey is a biologist, educator, science communicator and artist. Her current interests are heavily embedded in the cultures of biological sciences and the arts, and she employs her skills to produce scientific outcomes as well as artistic/philosophical outputs that places her scientific work in a larger cultural context. She has a PhD in visual neuroscience/ecology and biological arts from the University of Western Australia (UWA), and previously graduated with honours from The University of Western Australia (UWA), Faculty of Science with a Bachelor of Science (Microbiology and Medical Genetics majors).

PhD title - Other-Worlds: Encounters with the visual perception of lungfishes through science and art

Audrey Bester n茅e Appudurai is the first PhD Candiate to conduct an interdisciplinary art/science research project in Western Australia. The PhD was completed through SymbioticA, The Centre of Excellence in Biological Arts, School of Anatomy, Physiology and Human Biology, and The Neuroecology Group, School of Animal Biology, The University of Western Australia. The project was supervised by Dr. Ionat Zurr, Professor Shaun P. Collin and Associate Professor Nathan S. Hart.

The project explored the visual perception of lungfishes, living fossils capable of breathing through air and water, and linked to humans by being the closest living ancestor to all land vertebrates. The unique methodology utilized biological science and visual art, as well as cultural studies that traced the history of human cultural interactions with this significant animal. Scientific data generated through anatomical, electrophysiological and behavioural experimentation contributed to the emerging field of lungfish visual ecology, and artistic research, including 3 public exhibitions, provides a more sensorium speculation of the lungfish visual experience in order to reflect on how we (humans) produce knowledge of non-humans and the limitations of these methods.

Tutor for practical components of the art and science units VISA2214 (Aesthetic
      Crossovers of Art and Science) and ANHB8511 (Advanced Art and Life Manipulation).
      Responsible for managing and carrying out tutorial classes, assessments, interactive
      
      sessions, and critical feedback for classes of up to 12 students.

jobs.description:
In my time at the NSW Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, I worked on a high-profile trial before the NSW Supreme Court, in both a legal and an administrative capacity. Part of my role involved examining complex parts of the brief of evidence to produce summaries and insights that would be used in court proceedings, as well as conducting legal research for submissions on pre-trial applications. 

I had considerable exposure to counsel and court practice.

As PASS tutor, I was responsible for organising classes and material to teach Microeconomics to first year students. This involved liaising with the head lecturer and other tutors, and my classes had a consistently high attendance. I was also involved in helping facilitate the transition of these students from high-school to university in an academic context.

The UNSW Law Society (LawSoc) is the representative student society for all law students. In this role, I helped establish the new Public Interest Careers portfolio. This involved me contacting organisations, such as the Australian Government Solicitor, the ACCC and community legal centres, to create career opportunities for students.

I also contributed to the development of the first Public Interest Careers Guide, which was read by over one thousand students at UNSW.

      hundred students. This involved preparing lessons and providing them with support
      both inside and outside the classroom. I was ran the 'Secrets to HSC Success' Seminar
      
      monthly at the Hurstville centre.

My work as an Investment Banking Intern at CIMB was primarily in the infrastructure

In my role as a Consultant for 180 Degrees, I operated with a team to analyse the existing framework of volunteer recruitment and retention for a non-profit organisation. Subsequent to this, I developed an innovative new strategy which including the implementation of an incentive rewards scheme and a reformed social media presence.

This strategy was then presented to the Board of Directors, and was subsequently adopted, seeing a 65% increase in recruitment.

jobs.description:
My principal areas of practice are in relation to marketing / advertising, commercial agreements, brand protection, trade marks, copyright and regulatory compliance.  I practice in both contentious and non-contentious intellectual property matters.  From August 2017 to date, I have also undertaken a part-time virtual secondment with Amazon Web Services (AWS).

I regularly advise in relation to general commercial agreements, as well as IP specific agreements.  In addition, I regularly provide advice in relation to marketing / advertising issues (including review of marketing collateral across a range of media), and advise in relation to consumer protection issues under the Australian Consumer Law.  I also provide regulatory advice, particularly in relation to food regulation (including food label reviews), trade promotions (including reviews of terms & conditions) product regulation and charitable fundraising.

I act for a wide range of local and international clients in the management of trade mark portfolios and related branding, marketing and advertising activities.  This involves the day-to-day running of a large number of domestic and international trade mark portfolios.  In this capacity, I assist with trade mark enforcement and protection, including trade mark prosecution and opposition matters.  

I have also recently been involved with large IP litigious matters.  I was part of the team acting for Moroccanoil Israel Limited in current Federal Court proceedings.  These proceedings related to claims of trade mark infringement, misleading and deceptive conduct and passing off.  Prior to that, I was part of the team representing Commercial Radio Australia in a Copyright Tribunal proceeding. This proceeding related to the appropriate licensing scheme structure and fees for the internet simulcast of sound recordings in radio programs.

I completed two graduate rotations in 2013/2014, the first in the Tax team (October
      2013 - March 2014) and the second in the Intellectual Property team (March 2014 -
      
      October 2014).

Restructuring & Insolvency

I have assisted on caseloads for a variety of high profile collapses. Ji-Shen is a Senior Lawyer who advises on multijurisdictional commercial transactions. At Clayton Utz, he works across Real Estate and Corporate / M&A / Capital Markets practice groups. He focuses primarily on major corporate transactions, real estate M&A and government tenders. He has particular expertise on Foreign Investment Review Board regulatory compliance issues. Ji-Shen is an advocate of creating inclusive and diverse workplaces, and the immense impact it has on empowering employees to achieve their best. He currently sits on the Clayton Utz LGBTI diversity Committee and has previously served on the Law Institute of Victoria's LIVOut LGBTI Taskforce.

Ji-Shen holds a First Class Honours degree from the Australian National University where he studied Law and Art History and Curatorship.

jobs.description:
Our lawyers have a wealth of knowledge and experience from diverse industry backgrounds to assist their clients. We specialize in providing legal services to the I T, Electronics, Mechanical Engineering, Construction, Healthcare, and Accounting fields.

We deal in most areas of law, and provide varied legal services, We also provide professional advice on a broad range of corporate transactions and commercial law matters. Our focus is always on the practical and effective implementation of the business goals set by our clients, and creating innovative legal solutions to meet our clients needs.

We handle matters for both national and international clients, and provide risk management and mitigation services. Our expertise is reflected by our exclusive clientele, some of whom are public companies for which we provide corporate advice, and legal services for all facets of their businesses.  

We know and understand big business, and can provide professional advice specific to their needs.

Many clients' have gained the benefits and advantages of adding our expertise and experience to their panel of lawyers, and we regularly assist in-house counsels of various clients with our innovations and precedents by challenging and moulding various areas of law particularly laws touching on commercial contracts, property and consumer law. 

Want to know more about the personalised, and tailored services packages we can offer? then contact Cogent Lawyers now:  (02) 8379 1227 we will be pleased to assist.

Dynamic Law firm specialising in providing lawyers with unique multi discipline skill sets. In this role, I managed all aspects of all the firms鈥� litigation matters.

Notably, in one particular matter I was instrumental in challenging over 100 years of common law affecting property and mortgage laws in New South Wales. Although, we lost at first instance before the Supreme Court of New South Wales, later (on appeal) at the conclusion of the hearing before a full Court of the Supreme Court of Appeal it was evident that our case was going to succeed.

Obtaining a positive judgment in the Court of Appeal would result in mortgages on title of properties in New South Wales being open to challenge by non-parties to the contracts and the mortgages. Four of Australia鈥檚 major banks were involved in this case and they settled out of court on the basis that the Court of Appeal would not hand down its judgment. There were 14 parties in total and the Court of Appeal judgment was adjourned 4 times to allow for the settlement to be filed. Needless, to say my clients now enjoy an unencumbered property.
